node.plaintext:
Braxton Woodham has been at the forefront of envisioning and leading the
development and commercialization of scaled software products and platforms for
more than 20 years. He currently serves as President of Unfinished Labs, and was
formerly the Chief Technology and Product Officer at Fandango, where he was
responsible for product development and technology operations for Fandango
Ticketing, Rotten Tomatoes, Fandango NOW (TVOD service with over 90k titles),
Movietickets.com, Flixster, MovieClips, Ingresso (ticketing in Brazil), and
Fandango.lat. While at Fandango he led technical strategy, diligence and
integration efforts for eight acquisitions. Prior to Fandango, Braxton was
co-founder, President, and Chief Technology Officer at Sun Basket, a
personalized meal platform based in San Francisco. He is currently a board
member at Sun Basket, as well as co-founder and Executive Chairman at
kuma.capital, a software company providing a platform and applications for
systematic digital asset trading.

Braxton previously co-founded Tap11, a real-time media analytics platform which
was acquired by AVOS Systems in 2011. Earlier he was the CTO of InfoSpace’s
mobile division where he was responsible for the infrastructure that serviced
approximately three quarters of all mobile web traffic in North America. Braxton
joined InfoSpace through the acquisition of Moviso, where he led the development
of the V4 Digital Media Platform, which scaled by more than 100 times to
generate over $1.5 billion in revenue across US, European and Australian mobile
carriers. Prior to joining Moviso / InfoSpace, Braxton served as Executive
Director of Technology at Sony Music Digital Media Ventures, where he focused on
new Internet initiatives including Keyhole, which was acquired by Google and
relaunched as Google Earth. Earlier Braxton served as Lead Propulsion Engineer
for two Atlas missions and was a Captain in the United States Air Force. He has
a B.E. in Mechanical Engineering with honors from Vanderbilt University.

Braxton is the President of Unfinished Labs.

node.plaintext:
Project Liberty began at an event in 2019 on Liberty Island, focused on a
question: Could we change technology to restore and then scale humanity’s
capacity to build trusted relationships, which are the bedrock of healthy
societies, economies, and democracies? We identified the possibility for just
such a model in what may seem an unexpected place: the concept at the core of
the social network itself, known as the social graph. The term "social graph"
isn't widely known beyond Internet technology circles, but it is a digital
representation of all the relationships between members of a social network.
When we use a social network—as nearly 60 percent of the world does—all the ways
we connect, learn, transact, consume, and contribute traverse this essential
online circuitry. The social graph holds immense power over us all, and the
largest social networks are owned and controlled by powerful, private companies,
each built on its own proprietary social graph. The key to change lies in the
power of combining our social networks in one unified social graph that is free
from corporate control and rewards innovators and value creators directly.

Late in 2019, Unfinished Labs [https://www.unfinishedlabs.io/] assembled a team
and began to build that social graph protocol. The Decentralized Social
Networking Protocol (DSNP) is the result of their work, and DSNP.org is an
independent stewardship organization that serves as the home for ongoing
development of the DSNP specifications and open source code.

Opening the social graph for building is only the beginning. To enable a vibrant
ecosystem of apps that leverage the new social graph, Unfinished Labs continues
to develop essential tooling for rapid testing and launch of new social apps and
integration of social features into existing apps.

The social graph holds immense power over us all, and the largest social networks are owned and controlled by powerful, private companies, each built on its own proprietary social graph. The key to change lies in the power of combining our social networks in one unified social graph that is free from corporate control and rewards innovators and value creators directly.

node.plaintext:
The mission of DSNP.org is to support community development of open source
technology and protocols to create a single, universally accessible, and
decentralized social graph.

Our primary activity is stable and responsible stewardship of the Decentralized
Social Networking Protocol (DSNP). Because the protocol is available for anyone
to use, for both commercial and non-commercial purposes, our role is to help
implementors ensure the integrity and decentralized governance of the unified
and universally accessible social graph. The integrity of the graph includes
DSNP's promises about people's privacy and control over their communications.
 To serve these goals:

 * We provide a framework for DSNP-related working groups and ongoing standards
   development (based loosely on the role of the IETF in Internet governance),
   and help participants interface with other standards bodies when needed.
 * We keep watch for unanticipated or adversarial centralization, and coordinate
   community response as needed. Decentralized systems usually have centralizing
   forces circulating within them, for example nodes that grow especially large
   and influential, and preserving true decentralization can sometimes require
   coordinated action.
 * We arrange virtual and in-person gatherings of DSNP implementors, both to
   help accelerate development and usage of DSNP as a technology and to ensure
   that there is a community of mutually familiar implementors who share a
   vision of DSNP's purpose.
 * We coordinate legal defense of DSNP if necessary (e.g., community patent
   defense).
 * We work transparently and in public as much as possible.  Anyone should be
   able to see what what DSNP.org is doing without necessarily being a
   participant.

Control of content flowing over DSNP is not within the scope of DSNP.org's
mission, and we do not take part in development of content filtering policy;
that is for nodes in and gateways to the graph to decide and implement.  Our
goal is maintenance of the protocol and the decentralized social graph in such a
way that the public interest is well-served by having individuals use DSNP-based
technologies to communicate.

  • We provide a framework for DSNP-related working groups and ongoing standards development (based loosely on the role of the IETF in Internet governance), and help participants interface with other standards bodies when needed.
  • We keep watch for unanticipated or adversarial centralization, and coordinate community response as needed. Decentralized systems usually have centralizing forces circulating within them, for example nodes that grow especially large and influential, and preserving true decentralization can sometimes require coordinated action.
  • We arrange virtual and in-person gatherings of DSNP implementors, both to help accelerate development and usage of DSNP as a technology and to ensure that there is a community of mutually familiar implementors who share a vision of DSNP's purpose.

node.plaintext:
DSNP.org is governed by a Board of Directors, with the assistance of an Advisory
Council. To provide a stable base for early growth, the initial Board has a
majority representation from our founding partner, Unfinished, while also
including a significant number of independent directors. As the DSNP ecosystem
expands and matures, we will also be updating the process for selecting Board
members accordingly, with the expectation that Unfinished will become just one
constituent among many, so that the Board represents the composition of the
entire DSNP ecosystem, as befits community-governed public infrastructure.

Why an entity?
DSNP.org is an independent entity to ensure that the community of people and
organizations that depend on the protocol have a place to convene, discuss
matters of common concern, and take collective action where appropriate.  One
such matter is the technical development of the protocol itself, of course:
establishing the standards that make DSNP-enabled applications mutually
compatible, and updating those standards to meet the community's functionality
needs in ways that align with DSNP's mission and values.  Another example is
addressing regulatory concerns, including helping regulators understand what
DSNP is and what it does.  These kinds of activities are best coordinated by an
independent entity that is able to foster discussion among a diverse group of
stakeholders without being beholden to any single stakeholder. DSNP.org also
needs to be able to adjust its governance to preserve this role in a changing
environment, which means it should not be subject to the governance constraints
of any other organization.
node.html:
DSNP.org is governed by a Board of Directors, with the assistance of an Advisory Council. To provide a stable base for early growth, the initial Board has a majority representation from our founding partner, Unfinished, while also including a significant number of independent directors. As the DSNP ecosystem expands and matures, we will also be updating the process for selecting Board members accordingly, with the expectation that Unfinished will become just one constituent among many, so that the Board represents the composition of the entire DSNP ecosystem, as befits community-governed public infrastructure.

Why an entity?

DSNP.org is an independent entity to ensure that the community of people and organizations that depend on the protocol have a place to convene, discuss matters of common concern, and take collective action where appropriate.  One such matter is the technical development of the protocol itself, of course: establishing the standards that make DSNP-enabled applications mutually compatible, and updating those standards to meet the community's functionality needs in ways that align with DSNP's mission and values.  Another example is addressing regulatory concerns, including helping regulators understand what DSNP is and what it does.  These kinds of activities are best coordinated by an independent entity that is able to foster discussion among a diverse group of stakeholders without being beholden to any single stakeholder. DSNP.org also needs to be able to adjust its governance to preserve this role in a changing environment, which means it should not be subject to the governance constraints of any other organization.

node.plaintext:
Karl Fogel [https://duckduckgo.com/?q=karl+fogel] has been an open source
developer, author, project manager, and specialist in collaborative development
techniques since 1992.

In 1995, he and Jim Blandy co-founded Cyclic Software, the first company
offering commercial support for CVS, the free software version control system;
in 1997 he added support for anonymous read-only repository access to CVS. In
1999 he wrote Open Source Development With CVS [http://cvsbook.red-bean.com/] 
(Coriolis OpenPress). From 2000-2006, he worked for CollabNet, Inc
[http://collab.net/] as a founding developer in the Subversion
[http://subversion.apache.org/] project. In 2005 he wrote Producing Open Source
Software: How to Run a Successful Free Software Project
[http://producingoss.com/] (O'Reilly Media).

He has since been an open source specialist at Google [http://google.com/], at 
Canonical Ltd [http://canonical.com/] (where he helped release the Launchpad.net
[http://launchpad.net/] code), at O'Reilly Media [http://oreilly.com/], and at 
Code for America [http://codeforamerica.org/] / Civic Commons
[http://civiccommons.org/], where he worked with non-profits and government
agencies to release and manage open civic technology projects.  Karl has also
been a board member at the Open Source Initiative [http://opensource.org/], an 
Open Internet Tools Project Fellow [http://openitp.org/] at the New America
Foundation [http://newamerica.net/], and is a member of the Apache Software
Foundation [http://apache.org/].

In addition to his books, some of his articles on collaborative development are:
“Teams and Tools
[https://www.red-bean.com/kfogel/beautiful-teams/bt-chapter-21.html]”, “
Dissecting The Myth That Open Source Software Is Not Commercial
[http://blog.ieeesoftware.org/2016/04/dissecting-myth-that-open-source.html]”, “
What's the Return on Investment for Open?
[http://civiccommons.org/2010/10/roi-of-open/]”, “What Is Free Software?”, “
Open
source mistakes for enterprise newcomers
[https://www.oreilly.com/ideas/open-source-mistakes-for-enterprise-newcomers]”
(with James Vasile), and “Be Open from Day One, not Day N
[http://civiccommons.org/2011/01/be-open-from-day-one/]”.

Further information can be found in his GitHub
[https://github.com/kfogel?tab=activity], Twitter [https://twitter.com/kfogel],
and Identi.ca [https://identi.ca/kfogel] accounts, among other places.

node.plaintext:
Andrew McLaughlin is President & COO of Assembly OSM [http://assemblyosm.com/],
a new, fast-growing, venture-backed startup working to transform the way we
build high-rise residential architecture. Using advanced digital design and an
innovative, manufacturing-based direct-to-fabrication-and-assembly delivery
system, Assembly OSM is building greener, higher-quality, more affordable
housing in dramatically less time than conventional construction.

Andrew is a co-founder and partner at Higher Ground Labs
[https://www.highergroundlabs.com/], a startup accelerator and venture investor
that backs and builds for-profit startups that help progressives win election
campaigns and policy fights.  Since 2017, Higher Ground Labs has seed-invested
in more than 36 startups, and led a number of Series A rounds and follow-on
financings.

Andrew is a venture partner at betaworks [http://betaworks.com/], a technology
and media startup studio and seed investor based in NYC. As a partner at
betaworks from 2012-2016, Andrew was an operator, a company and product builder,
a business strategist, and an early-stage tech investor. He served as CEO of two
betaworks companies, Digg [http://digg.com/] and Instapaper
[http://www.instapaper.com/], and in 2016 worked at Medium [https://medium.com/]
, leading a set of teams including corporate development, new business
initiatives, editorial, outreach, international, and enterprise services. From
2012-2019, Andrew served on the board of Chartbeat [http://chartbeat.com/], a
real-time data analytics service founded at betaworks.

Andrew chairs the board of Access Now [https://www.accessnow.org/], a
not-for-profit devoted to defending and extending the digital rights of
activists, journalists, and citizens at risk around the world. He is a director
of Public Knowledge [http://publicknowledge.org/], which promotes freedom of
expression, an open Internet, and a vibrant public domain.

In 2018, Andrew joined the board of the Electric Coin Company
[https://electriccoin.co/], which builds and supports technology for Zcash
[https://z.cash/], a decentralized, privacy-protective digital currency built on
remarkably strong cryptographic science.  Zcash is the first widespread
implementation of zk-SNARKs [https://z.cash/technology/zksnarks/], a powerful
form of zero-knowledge cryptography.

In 2017-18, Andrew was the founding executive director of the Tsai Center for
Innovative Thinking at Yale [http://city.yale.edu/], a new, university-wide
initiative to support students across disciplines to tackle real-world problems
in innovative ways.  Tsai CITY is a transformative addition to the Yale campus,
dedicated to advancing the university's goal [http://president.yale.edu/goals] 
of creating an interdisciplinary learning environment that cultivates
innovators, leaders, pioneers, creators, and entrepreneurs in all fields and for
all sectors of society. Through a wide range of programs, intensives, and
initiatives, Tsai CITY coaches and supports students as they conceive, research,
develop, prototype, test, build, iterate, and launch their visions -- whether a
for-profit startup, a mission-driven nonprofit, a social justice movement, or an
experimental theater company.

From 2009-2011, Andrew was a member of President Obama
[https://barackobama.com/]'s senior White House staff, serving as Deputy Chief
Technology Officer of the United States.  In that role, Andrew was responsible
for advising the President on Internet, technology, and innovation policy,
including open government, cybersecurity, online privacy and free speech,
spectrum policy, federal R&D priorities, entrepreneurship, and the creation of
open technology standards and platforms for health care, energy efficiency, and
education.

In 2008-2009, he served on the Obama/Biden presidential transition team
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidential_transition_of_Barack_Obama], as a
member of the Technology, Innovation and Government Reform
[https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=1&v=InI5n3NTvR4] cluster.  In
2015-16, Andrew was a member of the human rights and tech & innovation advisory
committees of Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign.

From 2003-2009, Andrew was Director of Global Public Policy
[http://googlepublicpolicy.blogspot.com/] at Google [http://google.com/],
leading the company's work on issues like freedom of expression and censorship,
surveillance and law enforcement, privacy, copyrights and trademarks, regulation
of Internet and telecommunications networks, wireless radio spectrum, national
security, trade policy, patent reform, and online child protection. Google’s
first public policy hire, Andrew established, built and managed a 50-person
worldwide team based in Brussels, London, Paris, Madrid, Milan, Berlin,
Amsterdam, Stockholm, Dublin, Brasilia, Buenos Aires, Tokyo, Seoul, Beijing,
Sydney, Ottawa, Washington, and San Francisco. Beyond policy, Andrew was a
co-lead on Google's Africa [http://google-africa.blogspot.com/] strategy and
operations.

From 1999-2003, Andrew helped launch, establish, and manage ICANN
[http://www.icann.org/], the Internet's technical coordinating organization,
serving as Vice President, Chief Policy Officer, and Chief Financial Officer.
From 1998-2005, Andrew was a Senior Fellow at Harvard Law School
[http://law.harvard.edu/]'s Berkman Center for Internet and Society
[http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/]. In 2002-2003, Andrew taught a course on digital
democracy at Harvard Law School while working on Internet and telecom law reform
projects in a number of developing countries, including Ghana, Mongolia, Kenya,
Afghanistan, and South Africa. He was a co-founder of CIPESA
[http://www.cipesa.org/], a technology policy think-tank and advocacy center
based at Makerere University [http://mak.ac.ug/] in Uganda. Andrew served as a
member of the Board of Directors of Bridges.org
[http://www.ethanzuckerman.com/blog/2014/01/14/rest-in-peace-teresa-peters/], an
international technology policy not-for-profit based in Cape Town.

From 2011-2012, Andrew was EVP of Tumblr [http://tumblr.com/], responsible for
the international, community, outreach, editorial, marketing, and support teams.

Andrew is a member of the advisory board of Swing Left [https://swingleft.org/],
which was founded in 2016 to help Americans everywhere work effectively to flip
the U.S. House to a Democratic majority.

Andrew is a Future Tense Fellow [http://futuretense.newamerica.net/] at the New
America Foundation [http://newamerica.net/]; an advisor to Data & Society
[http://www.datasociety.net/], a research institute focused on social, cultural,
and ethical issues arising from data-centric technological development; a member
of the Advisory Council of the Open Technology Fund
[https://www.opentech.fund/about/people]; a co-chair of the digital strategy
committee of the Brooklyn Public Library [https://www.bklynlibrary.org/]; and a
member of New York Public Radio [https://www.wnyc.org/]’s Digital Task Force. He
has served as a member of the Partnership for New York City’s Innovation Council
[http://innovateinnyc.org/].

Andrew served on the boards of Code for America [http://codeforamerica.org/] 
(2011-13) and the Sunlight Foundation [http://sunlightfoundation.com/],
(2011-2016). In 2014-15, he was a senior fellow in cybersecurity and Internet
governance at Columbia University [http://www.columbia.edu/]'s School of
International and Public Affairs [https://sipa.columbia.edu/]; in 2011-12, he
was a non-resident fellow at Stanford Law's Center for Internet & Society
[http://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/] and at Princeton's Center for Information
Technology Policy [https://citp.princeton.edu/]. In 2011-12, Andrew was a
Lecturer in Law at Stanford Law School [http://www.law.stanford.edu/], teaching
a course
[http://blogs.law.stanford.edu/newsfeed/2011/05/05/andrew-mclaughlin-to-join-center-for-internet-society-as-non-residential-fellow/] 
on "Freedom of Speech in a Digitally Interconnected World". In 2011-13, Andrew
was a member of the Commission on Innovation
[http://www.bbg.gov/press-release/bbgs-commission-on-innovation-holds-first-meeting-in-new-york/] 
of the U.S. Broadcasting Board of Governors [http://www.bbg.gov/].

After clerking on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
[http://www.ca8.uscourts.gov/], Andrew started his career as a lawyer at Jenner
& Block in Washington, D.C., where he focused on appellate and constitutional
litigation. He was a member of the legal team that challenged the U.S.
government's first Internet censorship law, resulting in the Supreme Court's
landmark 1997 Internet free speech ruling in Reno vs. ACLU
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reno_v._American_Civil_Liberties_Union]. From
1997-98, Andrew served as legal counsel in the U.S. House of Representatives
[http://www.house.gov/].

In 2000, Time Magazine [http://time.com/] named Andrew one of its Digital Dozen
for the new century. In 2001, he was named a Global Leader for Tomorrow by the 
World Economic Forum [http://www.weforum.org/]. He is a fellow of the Young
Leaders Forum [http://www.ncuscr.org/ylf] of the National Committee on US-China
Relations [http://www.ncuscr.org/].

Andrew holds a B.A. in history from Yale University [http://www.yale.edu/], and
a J.D. from Harvard Law School [http://law.harvard.edu/].

Growing up, Andrew attended Highland Elementary School
[http://www.sylvaniaschools.org/highlandelementary_home.aspx] in Sylvania, Ohio; 
Widsten Elementary School
[https://www.swnewsmedia.com/lakeshore_weekly/news/local/widsten-school-the-pueblo-on-the-hill/article_d7787085-8305-5366-8249-bd409a4da107.html] 
in Wayzata, Minnesota; Longfellow Elementary School
[https://www.fargo.k12.nd.us/longfellow] and Ben Franklin
[https://www.fargo.k12.nd.us/benfranklin]Junior High School
[http://library.ndsu.edu/fargo-history/?q=content/benjamin-franklin-school] in
Fargo, North Dakota; the American Community School
[https://www.acs-schools.com/cobham] in Cobham, Surrey, UK; and Neil A.
Armstrong Senior High School [http://ahs.rdale.org/] in Plymouth, Minnesota,
from which he graduated in 1987.  Over summers, he attended the Trollwood
Performing Arts School [http://www.trollwood.org/] in Fargo, the International
Music Camp [http://www.internationalmusiccamp.com/] in Dunseith, North Dakota,
and the Minnesota Institute for Talented Youth [http://www.mity.org/] in St.
Paul, at which point he had to start working summer jobs at places like the 
Sheraton Park Place Hotel [http://slphistory.org/sheratonparkplace/], Dayton's
Department Store [http://lileks.com/mpls/daytons/index.html], and the kitchen of
the celebrated Red Lobster of Golden Valley
[http://www.yelp.com/biz/red-lobster-golden-valley].

Current + evergreen obsessions:

 * Cities, architecture, urbanism, transit, civic tech, economic opportunity,
   and sustainability.
 * The Internet, tech, artificial intelligence and machine learning, startups,
   consumer and SaaS product design, the media industry, business strategy, and
   global scaling.
 * Public policy, constitutional law, free speech, privacy, rule of law, and
   democratic vitality.
 * Progressive politics, political theory and philosophy, American and world
   history.
 * Books, bikes, beagles.

Andrew McLaughlin is President & COO of Assembly OSM, a new, fast-growing, venture-backed startup working to transform the way we build high-rise residential architecture. Using advanced digital design and an innovative, manufacturing-based direct-to-fabrication-and-assembly delivery system, Assembly OSM is building greener, higher-quality, more affordable housing in dramatically less time than conventional construction.

Andrew is a co-founder and partner at Higher Ground Labs, a startup accelerator and venture investor that backs and builds for-profit startups that help progressives win election campaigns and policy fights.  Since 2017, Higher Ground Labs has seed-invested in more than 36 startups, and led a number of Series A rounds and follow-on financings.

Andrew is a venture partner at betaworks, a technology and media startup studio and seed investor based in NYC. As a partner at betaworks from 2012-2016, Andrew was an operator, a company and product builder, a business strategist, and an early-stage tech investor. He served as CEO of two betaworks companies, Digg and Instapaper, and in 2016 worked at Medium, leading a set of teams including corporate development, new business initiatives, editorial, outreach, international, and enterprise services. From 2012-2019, Andrew served on the board of Chartbeat, a real-time data analytics service founded at betaworks.

Andrew chairs the board of Access Now, a not-for-profit devoted to defending and extending the digital rights of activists, journalists, and citizens at risk around the world. He is a director of Public Knowledge, which promotes freedom of expression, an open Internet, and a vibrant public domain.

In 2018, Andrew joined the board of the Electric Coin Company, which builds and supports technology for Zcash, a decentralized, privacy-protective digital currency built on remarkably strong cryptographic science.  Zcash is the first widespread implementation of zk-SNARKs, a powerful form of zero-knowledge cryptography.

In 2017-18, Andrew was the founding executive director of the Tsai Center for Innovative Thinking at Yale, a new, university-wide initiative to support students across disciplines to tackle real-world problems in innovative ways.  Tsai CITY is a transformative addition to the Yale campus, dedicated to advancing the university's goal of creating an interdisciplinary learning environment that cultivates innovators, leaders, pioneers, creators, and entrepreneurs in all fields and for all sectors of society. Through a wide range of programs, intensives, and initiatives, Tsai CITY coaches and supports students as they conceive, research, develop, prototype, test, build, iterate, and launch their visions -- whether a for-profit startup, a mission-driven nonprofit, a social justice movement, or an experimental theater company.

Google’s first public policy hire, Andrew established, built and managed a 50-person worldwide team based in Brussels, London, Paris, Madrid, Milan, Berlin, Amsterdam, Stockholm, Dublin, Brasilia, Buenos Aires, Tokyo, Seoul, Beijing, Sydney, Ottawa, Washington, and San Francisco. Beyond policy, Andrew was a co-lead on Google's Africa strategy and operations.

node.plaintext:
James Vasile [https://startpage.com/?query=james%20vasile] has over twenty years
experience as a user, developer, advocate and advisor in the free and open
source software world. His expertise is in software licensing and
community-building, as well as non-profit and small business startup. He focuses
on free software and open source production, although his work and interests
often take him far beyond the world of software. Much of what James does
involves teaching people how to build successful businesses around free software
and ensuring licensing alignment in multisource FOSS stacks.  James's technical
experience also allows him to act as outsource CTO/Architect, due-diligence open
source expert, new venture advisor, fiscal sponsorship facilitator, and more.

In addition to his work with OTS, James was the founding Director of the Open
Internet Tools Project [http://openitp.org], which during his tenure originated
a variety of excellent community-based projects.  These include Techno-Activism
Third Mondays (a meetup that gathers people in over 20 cities around the world
every month), the Circumvention Tech Festival (which has become the Internet
Freedom Festival), and a 1000+ volunteer translation project now know as
Localization Lab.  He was also a founding board member and is now part owner of
Overview Services, which makes open source software that powers
Pulitzer-winning
data journalism
[http://overview.ap.org/blog/2014/05/the-document-mining-pulitzers/].

Previously, James was a Senior Fellow at the Software Freedom Law Center
[http://softwarefreedom.org], where he advised and supported a wide range of
free software efforts.

James was a Director of the FreedomBox Foundation
[http://freedomboxfoundation.org/].  He helped boot up and served on the board
of Open Source Matters, the non-profit behind Joomla. He remains active in
several technology development efforts. His FreedomBox work has been recognized
by an Innovation Award at Contact Summit 2011 as well as an Ashoka
ChangeMaker's
award for Citizen's Media
[http://www.freedomboxfoundation.org/news/AshokaChangemakers2/index.en.html].

James frequently speaks and writes about technology trends and free software.
His FreedomBox talk at Elevate Festival
[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9bDDUyJSQ9s], for example, has been received
well, and his writing on FOSS project management
[http://www.softwarefreedom.org/resources/2008/foss-primer.html] and work on 
extension licensing and derivative works
[https://wordpress.org/news/2009/07/themes-are-gpl-too/] have been widely read.

You can learn more about him from his GitHub activity
[https://github.com/jvasile] and his LinkedIn profile
[http://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=10459180&trk=tab_pro], or by connecting
with him on Twitter [https://twitter.com/jamesvasile].

node.plaintext:
Allison Randal is a software developer and open source strategist. She is a
board member of the Software Freedom Conservancy [https://sfconservancy.org/],
board member of the Open Infrastructure Foundation [https://openinfra.dev/],
board member of Open Usage Commons [https://openusage.org/], board member of the 
Perl Foundation [http://www.perlfoundation.org/], and co-founder of the FLOSS
Foundations [http://flossfoundations.org/] group for open source leaders.

Her first geek career was as a research linguist in eastern Africa, but her love
of coding led her away from natural languages to computer languages. In over 35
years as a programmer, she has developed everything from games, linguistic
analysis tools, websites, mobile apps, and shipping fulfillment systems, to
compilers, hypervisors, database replication, deployment automation, and talking
smart-home appliances, worked as a language designer, engineering manager, CTO,
conference organizer, and editor, written three books, and founded two
non-profit foundations and five companies.
